case_vignette: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after falling 7 feet onto a flat-top wooden post. On arrival, he is in severe pain and breathing rapidly. His pulse is 135/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. There is an impact wound in the left fourth intercostal space at the midaxillary line. Auscultation shows tracheal deviation to the right and absent breath sounds over the left lung. There is dullness to percussion over the left chest. Neck veins are flat. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are placed and intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I'm in severe pain and am breathing very rapidly.
Where is the pain located?
The pain is located on my left side, around the fourth rib area.
How long have you been experiencing this pain and rapid breathing?
I have been experiencing this pain and rapid breathing for about 15 minutes.
Do you have any history of heart disease or lung issues?
No, I don't have any history of heart disease or lung issues.
Do you feel any numbness or tingling in your arm or jaw along with the chest pain?
No, I do not feel any numbness or tingling in my arm or jaw.
Is there any history of similar pain in your family?
No, there is no history of similar pain in my family.
Final Diagnosis: Pneumothorax
